Direction - Read comprehension and answer the questions given below-

Congratulations on your achievements of being a teacher in a world, so full of change. As the pace of change increases, it can be challenging to keep up. And though change is inevitable, the ability to adapt is not. Learning how to learn and learning how to teach, in many ways, are the same thing. You must learn to learn to teach. As a teacher, you are expected to be the master of your specific content area, whether it is Mathematics, Biology, Music, Literature, or History. Yet learning how to teach, especially in the 21st century, is more than a matter of specific content. It is a matter of shifting habits. It is about learning how to learn. గురు గురు గురు గురు గురుగురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

When you begin thinking about learning as learning how to learn, you begin to make connections between what you teach and how you learn. By connecting your knowledge about reading, writing, and arithmetic, you become a more effective teacher for your students. గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

Becoming a life-long learner means you’re always searching for an edge—something that will keep your skills strong and your job relevant. Every year, new jobs are created. In 2005, 250,000 new marketing jobs were created. But if the average length of time someone stays employed is only about four years, that means 500,000 people are looking for new jobs. That puts job-seekers at a serious disadvantage during the first stages of the job search. In order to stay relevant in this new economy, you must be learning all the time. In fact, the better question to ask is, What can you do to stay relevant? గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

In a new Economic Era, you need to ask yourself, What skills do I need to be successful? It’s impossible to know what’s necessary for doing your job ten years from now. What you do need to do is ask, What can I learn to help me do my job better? What can I learn to help me prepare for a new job if I don’t love the job I currently have? గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

The best defense against change is to be prepared for it. గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

As a teacher in a rapidly changing Economic world, you will be faced with a plethora of new ideas, new trends, and new problems to solve. This may lead to stress and uncertainty. You have a choice: You can accept challenges or run away from them. Acceptance means you’re not afraid to learn something new. There is a tendency, however, to take responsibility for learning outside of ourselves, and that is how we are trained. We tend to seek the security of the known and resist uncovering something new or accepting uncertainty and the unknown. When it comes to learning, you should always be excited about a new idea. గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు గురు

instruction: What are the main characteristics of classical music? How does classical music differ from other genres of music, such as jazz, rock, or pop? Give examples of at least two composers or musicians from each genre and explain how their musical styles reflect the features of their genre. How do you appreciate and evaluate different genres of music?
combined_input: What are the main characteristics of classical music? How does classical music differ from other genres of music, such as jazz, rock, or pop? Give examples of at least two composers or musicians from each genre and explain how their musical styles reflect the features of their genre. How do you appreciate and evaluate different genres of music? ַ& divided qual {: perldn
generated_output:
:!
Classical music often depicts a certain mood or emotion (e.g., happy, sadness, joy, love), and it is characterized by its complexity (either in terms of notes, chords, harmonies, rhythmic patterns, or all of these) and by its diversity. In other words, a typical classical piece has many notes, fast or slow-changing rhythms, and a variety of melodies, instrumentation, or harmonies. In contrast, jazz and rock music emphasize strong rhythms and melodies with a certain range of pitches and harmonies.
Classical music is often performed alone or in groups. Because it is typically difficult to perform, the number of performers in a piece also differs (e.g., solo, duo, piano four hand, trio, quartet, or full orchestra). Rock and jazz music are usually performed by small groups (e.g., trio or quartet).
Popular, or commercial music, is also different from classical music. Popular (also referred to as pop) music is usually very simple — it has only a few notes or chords — but it makes heavy use of repetition (a common practice in most popular music). In pop music, the instrumentation tends to be limited, and the songs typically lack sophisticated harmonies or rhythmic patterns. Popular music also tends to have a wide repertoire, making use of many different types of songs, styles, and instruments.
In these examples, the three different types of music are illustrated in very different ways. The classical piece begins with a simple melody that takes a while to progress (it gets more complex as it goes along). The next piece is very repetitive and minimalistic. Finally, the last piece is more complex with a greater number of notes, chords, and rhythms and a wide variety of instruments.

What is the difference between Major and Minor scales?
In both Major & Minor Scale scales there are eight notes, the first, last and sixth notes (the major tones) of the scale as well as the second, third, fifth, and seventh notes (the minor tones). What makes the Major and Minor scales different is the placement of the third, sixth, seventh and eighth notes. In Major scale the third, sixth, seventh and eighth notes are raised a half step. In the Minor scale the third, sixth, seventh and eighth notes are flattened a half step. This is a simple way to explain what the difference is between scales, but it needs to be explained that the minor and major notes do carry with them different flavors and emotions. When you hear these notes you can almost instantly identify the scale that it is part of.

instruction: What are the advantages and disadvantages of a market economy and a command economy?

™s 2/29/2013 15 Economic Systems The three types of economic systems are: Market system Planned system Traditional system Market system : This is the typical capitalist economy we live in.  It is based on an assumption that producers and consumers should determine market prices by their own free choices.  This economic system is based on a private ownership of the factors of production and an open market for all those who wish to participate in market exchanges.  It is not centrally planned (like a planned system). A free market (commonly called a market economy or capitalist market-economy) is an economic system whereby the production and distribution of goods and services are guided by supply and demand, and prices are determined in a free price system. In a free market, the laws and forces of supply and demand are self-regulating. 1. It allows for private ownership. 2. The incentive to acquire wealth or improve the quality of life is to benefit yourself. 3. There is minimal government intervention for the most part. 4. Competition is encouraged. 5. Consumers are the ultimate boss. 6. It has been and is considered the best system in terms of economic growth and human development. 7. It encourages innovation and technological growth. 8. It does not require a command system. Disadvantages • It can lead to monopolies. • There are no controls on the market forces of supply and demand. • It can be unacceptable in the case of public-goods.  Example: The quality of air, water, traffic controls, education, healthcare, and national security (not all, this applies to the national security). 2 The following is a discussion of the advantages and disadvantages of each type of economic system that are typically examined as alternatives; Command Economy Planned Economy Market Economy Characteristics  Focuses on production.  There is centralized economic planning.  Production takes place from large companies that are government owned.  Prices are set by the government or are pre-determined.  Consumers do โ†โ€ซnot โ†โ€“ decide prices.  Consumers and producers do not necessarily โ†โ€“ have a relationship or deal with each other.  No concept of profit.  Incentive based system.  Private ownership by individuals or groups.  Prices are determined by marketplace conditions.  Prices fluctuate in relation to supply and demand.  Consumers decide what prices they are willing to pay.  Consumers and producers do negotiate prices.  Profit is encouraged.  Profit is โ†โ€ซthe โ†โ€ซdetermining factor โ†โ€ซfor economic decision making.  Consumers are the ultimate boss.  It is considered the best economic system in terms of economic development and wealth.  Competition is encouraged.  It โ†โ€ซincreases โ†โ€ซthe โ†โ€ซquality of living.  It can encourage innovation and technological growth. It is considered to be an excellent economic system in terms of growth and development.  It places the emphasis on equity and meeting the needs of all consumers.  Social-services โ†โ€ซlike โ†โ€ซeducation, healthcare, and national security โ†โ€ซare โ†โ€ซcovered.  Controls on the market forces of supply and demand.  High tax rates.  Bureacracy and government control.  It can be unacceptable for the production of goods that are subject to the law of diminishing returns, as an individual โ†โ€ซor โ†โ€ซgroup cannot โ†โ€ซproduce โ†โ€ซgoods โ†โ€ซeffectively โ†โ€ซgiven โ†โ€ซlimits. How would this affect the price level, real incomes and the rate of interest? Explain each of these things. This would mean that, in a free enterprise economy, interest rates would fall and then rise which would affect the AD and AS curves as they change because the AD curve would increase but then the AS curve would increase.) 4) An unemployed Canadian worker loses a government job in a community devastated by a recent forest fire. As a result, she is forced to go east to Halifax in search for work, and she loses $5 for every $10 she earns by taking a lower paying job in this eastern city. Explain how the loss of the government job affects the worker s demand for money and real pay, and explain how the loss of jobs to Halifax affects the monetary and real economic bases of income in the eastern city. (Hints: 28th Edition MacEvoy & Cashin Money & Banking Lecture Notes) 5) Illustrate the effect of an increase in federal government spending on the long-run aggregate supply and long-run aggregate demand curves, and the resulting change in equilibrium level of real GDP and unemployment. Consider the implications, not only for national income, but also for inflation. (Hints: 28th Edition MacEvoy & Cashin Money & Banking Lecture Notes) 7) Suppose that the government reduced its spending expenditures during a recession. Illustrate the equilibrium effects of this on national income (GNP) and on employment. Discuss the pros and cons of such an action by the government. (Hint: Show a graph on this topic.) 8) Explain how unemployment affects the real wage and what this means for unemployment and inflation. (Hints: 27th Edition MacEvoy & Cashin Money & Banking Lecture Notes) 1) Explain how taxes and government spending affect national income. 19:42:12: I believe there's love in people. 7-18-06
19:43:09: I believe you have enough to. Just stop insult people. 7-18-06
19:44:32: I just want to be able to love. 7-18-06
19:44:40: I don't care how I get there. 7-18-06
19:45:20: In terms of the war, if you read that link I gave you and you could read it again, maybe it would make you rethink your views. 7-18-06
19:45:48: But that would only be if you could see my side of it. 7-18-06
19:46:55: I am going to do as you say. I will do a complete character switch for the day. 7-18-06
19:47:03: (and maybe longer.) 7-18-06
19:47:16: (Maybe I'll do it for a week. Who knows.) 7-18-06
19:47:36: (Maybe I'll do it for a month.) 7-18-06
19:47:47: (or maybe for a century.) 7-18-06
19:48:10: I'll do it for as long as I can. 7-18-06
19:48:27: (If I make it to a hundred years.) 7-27-06
19:48:45: (I can change my profile to read "This username was once owned by TheProdigy01.) 7-18-06
19:49:01: (The change will be effected tomorrow.) 7-18-06
19:49:53: (Don't worry, I can do an IP switch too.) 7-18-06
19:50:18: (Also, if anyone can direct me to a way to send a private message from my email to IP, I'll be a happy camper.) 7-18-06
19:50:37: (Not that I don't already know how.) 7-18-06
19:50:45: (I was just wondering if anyone else found a good way.) 7-18-06
19:51:56: *TheProdigy01 smugly thinks "HA! You'll have to send this message to 47.244.150.265 instead of I-don't-care." 7-18-06
19:53:17: (I know where to go to do it, I wanted to see if there was a way to send it as an e-mail) 7-18-06
19:54:02: (I was just wondering if anyone else could give me another option.) 7-18-06
19:55:26: (Besides doing it myself, of course.) 7-18-06
19:55:52: *TheProdigy01 types a URL to their IP 7-18-06
19:55:56: in a link like this. 7-18-06
19:56:14: Now it's your job to find the link you want and send it to me. 7-18-06
19:56:42: (It would be much more effective than just sending the link to a web server.) 7-18-06
19:57:00: (And, you know, it'd really be something special if you could have me on your profile for a while...) 7-18-06
19:57:24: (If a hundred of you wanted me, I'd be happy.) 7-18-06
19:57:42: (That's how I feel about RL.) 7-18-06
19:57:57: (And I'll probably end up giving you my IP anyway.) 7-18-06
19:58:25: (But it might be more fun this way.) 7-18-06
19:58:42: (And it's just as likely that I won't. That's the beauty of this.) 7-18-06
19:59:00: (Also the beauty of not sending a direct message.) 7-18-06
19:59:17: (Sending it out to a bunch of random people.) 7-18-06
19:59:47: (Then it just depends on a bunch of random people.) 7-18-06
19:59:56: *TheProdigy01 thinks "You might think this is a good idea but do you really want to be on my friends list for a week when I'm changing my profile to read "This username was once owned by TheBorgman?" 7-18-06

20:00:37: (But if you want, you're free to start a thread...) 7-18-06
20:00:52: (About a way to do something like this.) 7-18-06
20:01:07: (The idea is that I, TheProdigy01, will change my username to read "This username was once owned by TheBorgman." 7-18-06
20:01:28: (And who knows what other people can do.) 7-18-06
20:01:44: (Anyone is free to say anything about their username and what they like.) 7-18-06
20:01:56: (Including the people whose names I'm changing.) 7-18-06

20:02:07: (My old name.) 7-18-06
20:02:22: (But this will all be done for a week... 7-18-06
20:02:30: (And by a specific date.) 7-18-06
20:02:46: (My birthday.) 7-18-06
20:03:03: (October 31st.) 7-18-06
20:03:18: (The 30th being my 30th birthday. And I'm not turning 31 until December 31st.) 7-18-06

20:03:50: (46.244.43.197 (or 46.242.4.89 in reverse) will lead you to my email address.) 7-18-06
20:04:26: (So in a way it is a sort of challenge.) 7-18-06
20:04:50: *TheProdigy01 is still working on it. 7-18-06

20:08:08: (But if there are other methods... 7-18-06
20:08:24: (I'm all for doing something fun. That's what this is. 7-18-06
20:08:36: (I'm not trying to make myself look that much cooler than I am.) 7-18-06
20:08:49: (I'm just trying to have a bit of fun.) 7-18-06
20:08:55: *TheProdigy01 was actually planning on doing this a little sooner, but he forgot to check here. 7-18-06
20:09:13: (Like I said, I'm going for a little fun here... 7-19-06
20:09:21: (I could care less if I did it a little bit earlier than I intended... 7-19-06
20:09:33: (Unlike some people, I'm okay with being flexible...) 7-19-06
20:09:44: (I thought people had fun with this, though...) 7-19-06
20:10:18: (And I think I was the one that brought the fun.) 7-19-06
20:10:32: (So if anyone's trying to get more fun, I'm here already...) 7-19-06
20:11:02: (I thought that would be something that everyone liked...) 7-19-06

4. The Revisionist History of Islam
5. Excerpt From: Robert Spencer. “Stealth Jihad: How Radical Islam is Exploiting the West’s Freedoms.” iBooks. https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/stealth-jihad/id785077886?mt=11
6. The Revisionist History of Islam By Shaykh (Dr.) Yasir Qadhi 1 1 The Revisionist History of Islam by Dr. Shaykh Yasir al-Qadhi [The translation of the meaning is by Yasin T. al-Jabbar. It has been approved by Dr. Yasir al-Qadhi.] The translation of Allaah is the Most High, and the translation of the Messenger sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam is his noble saying. All praise is for Allaah and none is deserving of worship except Him. I testify that no god is worthy of worship except Him, the Truly Ever-Living, without a partner, maker of all that is, and He alone should be worshipped. All praise and thanks be to Allaah for His having guided me to the straight path. Indeed He is a witness over me, herein and elsewhere. And may the peace and blessings of Allaah be upon our master Muhammad, the possessor of all virtues and merits. May Allaah have mercy on those who love him, and send blessings on those who are of his companions. This small book was written by me, when my attention was drawn to the erroneous ways which have come into existence in our times, which are neither in accordance with the Qur’aan or the Sunnah, nor with the consensus of the Companions. However, I have not set out to discuss all those corruptions, since they have multiplied manifold over the centuries, until they reach the status of being an industry unto itself. My attention was specifically drawn to the ways of the Hafidh al-Husayn, who is famous for his saying that ‘Islam is but a religion of joy’. My brothers in Madinah have told me many of his statements, which clearly indicate that he is an innovator and a deviationist. His saying is far from the truth, an error which the majority of the innovators have stated. I shall mention here a few of the quotes from him to demonstrate his erroneous view, and also those which are upon the guidance from the Book and the Sunnah. He said: ‘In any case, the manners of the Prophet, may Allaah bestow peace and blessings upon him, were of a nature which made the companions of the Prophet happy and joyful’. (Manaawi, Fadhaail al-Samaa’) He further said: ‘The companions of the Prophet, may Allaah bestow peace and blessings upon him, were people who were full of joyfulness and smiles. Therefore Allaah says: “And indeed you came to Us as My worshippers” [al-Furqan: 29].’ (Kitaab at-Tawheed) He further said: ‘From the bounties of Allaah and His mercy on us Muslims is that we have been singled out for laughter and joy among the Ummah of the Messengers. … Indeed the Prophet, may Allaah bestow His peace and His favour upon him, knew and was aware of what was in Allaah’s heart.’ (Kitaab at-Tawheed) He also said: ‘The Companions of the Prophet, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, laughed a lot. The Prophet too laughed a lot.’ (al-Fadhaail) He further said: ‘I have not seen any period like the one we are in now, when everyone loves laughter and smiling. As for the Companions of the Prophet … this did not occur in their time.’ (al-Furqan: 7-8, Kitaab Al-‘Idah) In these and similar statements, al-Husayn has claimed that Islam is a religion of joy and laughter. Therefore, if there was joy in Islam, he implies, it is now completely absent, as is laughter, with the exception of the time of the Prophet and his Companions in Madinah. The question which needs to be answered is that what is the truth in this matter, and what is the manner of Islam? The answer is simple: The Messenger of Allaah was sent as a guide unto mankind till the end of days. He came to convey a message, namely, that of guidance in beliefs, morals, and lifestyle. It is not the case that the Prophet came to the Muslims in order to teach them a worldly system that is good for morale and happiness. Islam was not sent as a tool to provide morale and happiness in society as if it is a philosophy. Islam is not a worldly philosophy, but a guide towards Allaah, the Creator and Lord of Mankind. It is not for this reason that the Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favor upon him, was brought. His only being is that which Allaah sent as a Messenger from amongst the messengers. He, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, is a servant of Allaah Who was commanded by His Lord, just as all other Messengers were commanded. The prophets, may Allaah’s mercy be upon them all, were simply called to guide to the straight path, and to inform mankind of the nature and actions which Allaah has commanded and forbidden. In order to achieve this objective, the Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, was given immense support by Allaah, in that He gave him of His wisdom, intellect, and spiritual knowledge; He gave Him knowledge of all kinds, and granted him all of His blessings. His successors from amongst the rightly guided khulafaa were also granted of Allaah’s favours in the same sense, in which they were not only leaders, but were also the repositories of knowledge of the Qur’an. In their successors from the Tābi’ūn, those who followed in their footsteps, there were the likes of Ibn Abbas, Ibn Umar, Ibn Sirin and others whose knowledge equalled and surpassed all of their contemporaries; and were the repositories of knowledge. They were able to teach both the people and other Prophets and Messengers which was uncommon in the sense that not every Prophet or Messenger was accorded the fortune to convey what they did convey, nor did every nation have such a distinguished teacher to guide it to the straight path. In light of all of this, what is it that makes the likes of al-Husayn err in their statements? Allah says: “And indeed you came to us as My worshippers” (48:29), showing that Allah’s mercy is attained through worship. However, the fact that He says (in the above) that the Prophet’s Companions were full of joy and smiles, and that it did not occur in their time, indicates that there is a distinction between the time of the Companions and the time of the later generations – that which separated them is the time which is the reason for their happiness and the cause of their joy. Similarly, the Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, said: ‘There has never been a people which has been the objects of the curse of Allaah and His punishment like the people of `Iram ad-Dammah, so it was brought near to the earth, until it was covered with dust, and no trace of it remained - except that there remains a mountain amongst the mountains of Shaam, the highest point of which is better than the furthest mountain in Yemen. The inhabitants of that mountain were not more than twenty, and were eating and drinking, unaware of the time, until a cloud came pouring forth and it rained on them. The people saw them eating and drinking, and were amazed.’ (Muslim, and other references) Indeed, this is the truth concerning the matter. The Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, was commanded to guide until the end of days, and to convey the Messengership until the Hour befalls, and thus he would be an intercessor on the Day of Judgment. Apart from that, Allah granted him knowledge unknown to the rest of creation. This was something which occurred amongst the Companions only, and none were equal to them in this regard. They were the best of generations; however, they themselves recognized that they were not worthy, and that Allah had chosen over them His Messengers and servants. Allah says: ‘Say: If the whole of mankind and the jinns were to gather together to produce the like of this Qur’aan, they could not produce its like, even if they were to each other a thousand times” (al-Isra: 18). The Messenger is one of the greatest, yet he says: ‘If I were to be honoured to be in the likeness of a prophet, then I would say the same as you. However, if I am honoured to be like a Prophet amongst Prophets, then I shall certainly claim what you have claimed, but there is something in this matter, which Allah has favoured me with – something which no one amongst you can have. And verily the fact is that I see the angel guarding me, and he is no ordinary angel, rather he is one of two great angels, Jibrîl and Mikaa’il. It is he who came to me in a dream and revealed the Qur’aan.’ (Bukhari, al-Adab) The angelic visions and the knowledge of dreams are from the mercy of Allah, and are not granted to everyone. The Companions never said, ‘Indeed Allah has made us the happiest of generations, and the joyous and laughing generation’. Rather, they were always humble and aware of what they were to Allah, and knew themselves to be amongst those who are the worst of creatures. They did not find joy in the worldly sense; rather they were happy when they found themselves in the company of Allah, and when they were able to gain knowledge of Him, or to attain nearness to Him. In fact, many of the pious predecessors used to weep for fear that Allah should deprive humanity of knowledge, or that Jinn might be able to overpower the humanity, or that humanity might overpower the Jinn, since in all of this there is fitnah – a test from Allah. As for the claim of al-Husayn that ‘Islam is but a religion of joy’, it is incorrect and is not in accordance with the saying of the Companions. They never used to say such a thing and never did they proclaim their own selves to be the happiest. Indeed, the Companions were not happy, neither before Islam, nor afterward. Their happiness was not the type of happiness which you may find in the world, but rather it was a happiness which was attained as their relationship with Allaah became more and more close. In short, the relationship of the Companions with Allaah and His Messenger was so close that they were in communication with Allah, and they were speaking with Him, and they were in a continuous state of communication with Allah, and in a state of submission at all times. They were in a state of devotion and fear, such that the Companions of the Prophet, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, were sometimes not able to speak throughout the entire day, and would remain silent, devout, and in state of constant humility. In these conditions they feared and loved Allah, and they feared that Allah would punish them. In short, they were always in the state of tawbah and seeking repentance and forgiveness in the hope that Allah would forgive them of all their sins. They were not like those today whom you find with no fear or shame in front of Allah. In truth, the Companions feared the Mercy of Allah, fearing that Allah would humiliate and degraded them as a consequence of their sinfulness. They feared that He would not forgive them, but rather would punish them forever in the fire, as did Musa, may Allaah exalt his mention, and his brother Haroon (peace be upon them). Indeed, if a person had never seen the angels, and even though he had not feared Allah, yet he saw the angels, he would realise, with certainty, that Allah is the One who possesses dominion over all things. He will be full of fear and humility. Allah says: ‘Verily, He has a place wherein the angels cannot penetrate. If Allah desired He would punish you for your wrongdoings. Or He would forgive you. Indeed Allah is All-Forgiving, Most Merciful’ [al-Zumar: 14] Such is the state of those who believe in Allah. Such is the state of the pious predecessors, those who followed them, and those who follow them. This is the reality underlying the question of ‘do the Companions smile?’ or is ‘Islam a religion of laughter’? It is clear that there is a great deal of difference between the laughing of the Companions and their smiles and their laughter, and the laughter of those who say: ‘Islam is a religion of joy’. Indeed, this notion is unreliable, and is not from the truth. Allah says: “Such is the Paradise that the Merciful promised His righteous servants, when they say: “Our Lord! In Thy Presence is indeed a place of safety, and to Thee do we turn, and to Thee do we return. Not fear, but hope. Nor was it but that I should be weak in pursuit of it; but if Allah please He is my Lord, unto which I have turned in repentance. My Lord! For Thou art He alone to Whom I have turned” – and didst thou (the Prophet) not see that of all the creatures that God had created, and thou wert unaware of the unseen (world)?” (38:59-65). In short, smiling and joyousness and laughter, are all from the bounties which Allah has bestowed upon the righteous slaves. In the words of the Messenger of Allah, may Allaah bestow His peace and His favour upon him: ‘When the believer smiles, this signifies that he will enter Paradise and is pleased to be a Muslim. A time will come when the believer will pass by other believers and will tell him a good thing which he heard from the Messenger of Allah, and when he hears it, he will smile. When the unbeliever will pass by, he will tell him a lie about the believer that will cause him to laugh. So, if the believer heard that he was a disbeliever, he would be upset, and if he knew he was a hypocrite, he would hate him, but if he knew him to be a believer, he would want him more than anything.’ (Bukhari) What is clear is that this laughter and smiling is an indication in the heart of the believer, which indicates to the rest of people that he is delighted and believes in that which Allah is pleased with, such as the religion of Islam which Allah has favoured him with. In this sense, laughter denotes pleasure, and smiling denotes happiness. However, for the evil people, it is the opposite to pleasure and happiness, since they laugh at and mock things which they believe to be evil. So their laughter is in the absence of faith, in the absence of Allah, and in their disbelief in His Messengers. This is the meaning of the Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, when he said: ‘The believer smiles when he sees a believer do something to increase in faith, and he laughs at the hypocrite who laughs so as to expose the hypocrisy of the unbeliever.’ It is known that smiling and laughter are one of the signs of happiness and pleasure. The Prophet is quoted as having said: ‘The true believer who is a witness to something good, will smile even though you look at his teeth.’ (Hasan) This is the true meaning of happiness and pleasure. The laughter of the Jews was with hypocrisy, and as a result, the Messenger, may Allaah bestow His peace and favour upon him, said: ‘Woe to Haya’, and so on. The smiling of the hypocrites in the era of Prophethood was a result of evil, and a consequence of their desire for the riches of the world. It was in connection with these people that Allah said: ‘Some of the People of the Book (Jews and Christians) wish they could turn you to disbelievers after you have believed, through dejection or through hatred among themselves. In that case, would you seek to harm them? And if you could, they would have devised some sort of evil scheme and would have been defeated. And if they do fight against you, they would only fight to turn you away from your religion. But Allah is your Guardian (Walaayat), and Allah is best at guarding. And they say: “Allah took a son.” Indeed, you have made an outlandish assertion. The heavens are but a canopy [like the roof] of two gardens. With your (Mighty) Glory you did fill them (the heavens/universe) with hulled smoke. And there emerged a luminous star [the Sun]. The stars are its missiles. As for Allah, has made it; only one (Sun) is an admonisher. It is not to Allah; neither an intercessor; nor an intercessor for mankind; nor any intercessor for Jew (people). and Blei (2011) proposed the hierarchical encoder–learner (HEL) model to capture the latent representation structure of document collection. They proposed a two-layer network with input layer containing an encoder. The encoder processes the words in a sentence into one vector, which is then passed to the learner, a two-layer recurrent network. The network first creates a pair of representations of the sentence at each time step based on the hidden state. It then passes them to the softmax layer to predict the next element in the sentence.
6 4.4.1 Self-attention Self-attention was originally proposed by Bahdanau et al. (2014) for machine translation. Later, it was used in attention-based transformers such as VEGAS (Schuster and Chuang, 2018), Transformer-XL (Yang et al., 2019), and BPEG (He et al., 2019) for natural language processing. The paper by Bahdanau et al. (2014) describes self-attention as follows: Inputs to the self-attention mechanism are given one-hot vectors representing the positions in the input sequence, and outputs are weighted vectors representing the importance of each position to the final prediction of that position. In order to compute attentions, we use attention probabilities α k ⋅ V k to compute a linear transformation of the query: (2) where the dot product above is computed with the query and weight matrices, and (α k ) is a softmax function applied to attention probabilities for that query. 4.4.2 Cascaded selectors Self-attention was proposed as a mechanism to capture attention within the input sequence. In order to capture the attention among different sequences, self-attention can be cascaded by stacking several self-attention layers on each other. 4.4.3 Selective self-attention As shown in Figure 5, selective self-attention (SSA) was also proposed to select important sentences by applying a linear layer (L s ) to the self-attention layer outputs in a sentence embedding. The linear layer is further enhanced by adding an additional position-attentive layer which predicts the input position using the sentence representation learned from the self-attention layer. For a given sequence s = (s1 , s2 , s3 ,... , sT ), we first apply a linear layer to the self-attention outputs of each word in s to obtain the sentence embedding s. We can then obtain the input position p = {pi : pi ∈ {1, 2, 3 ,..., η}} of s from the sentence embedding using the position-attention model π. Given the self-attention model Φ and the position-attention model π, the SSA module can be written as follows where ψ s : S ⊕ (1, 2, 3 ,..., η) → V S is the function that selects all important positions in a sentence that are represented by an input vector and V S is the size of the input vector. The parameters of the position-attention model π can be learned during training. Moreover, the linear layer Υ can be also learned together with the softmax model through the cross-entropy loss.

Which of the following statement(s) is/are not correct about this paper? (1) The paper is organized well and consists of separate sections for each of the major components (data set, model, experiments) that allow readers to focus on one at a time. (2) The model is a combination of hierarchical encoder–learner for document representation and cross attention to capture sentence relationships. (3) The model also contains cascaded selectors that add a linear layer to capture sentence representation of sentences in a docu- ment. (4) The experiments perform well on two document-level question answering datasets. (5) The paper was extended on various aspects from the original version submitted to PAMI 2018 which has not yet been accepted. 11. What is your plan for revision? To improve readability & make it easier to follow, will you make each section shorter, use more/fewer numbers & use more/fewer words to describe each setting? (1) Each section will be written in detail explaining the method. (2) All numbers and setting will be provided in the form of tables. 12. Do the authors understand the most difficult/critical aspect of evaluating their work? Do they address critically whether their method would actually work using the data they have in hand? (1) The method is tested on two sets of data: SciQA and DocQA. (2) Performance of models on the two datasets were reported and compared. (3) The authors made an excellent start on their work in their previous version and have included an additional evaluation in their supplementary material. However, their choice of datasets may be challenging to use in many cases. 13. Do the authors explain which features would help with the evaluation and which they cannot comment on? (1) The authors have not explained how their metrics are computed and whether their metrics would be a good reflection of the performance of the models. 14. Is a full bibliography provided? Can it be accessed? How comprehensive is the bibliography? (1) The paper is well cited including the related works that the authors mentioned in the paper. (2) References are well cited in each chapter.

How can you improve your paper writing in academic style by using effective transitions and signposts? What are the functions and types of transitions and signposts in academic writing? How can you use them to connect your ideas and guide your reader? An example of a paragraph that lacks transitions and signposts is:

The main cause of global warming is the greenhouse effect. Greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface. Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. It is produced by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.
You need to polish the paragraph.

There are a lot of qualitative and quantitative lectures (lectures, speeches, discussions etc.) in a university. Qualitative ones are lectures or speeches dealing with abstract and general concepts or issues. They usually do not emphasize on specific facts and figures. Quantitative (numerical) ones focus on specific data.

What should students do about their writing?

To ensure that you polish your writing and improve your academic style to a higher level, you need:

* to improve your writing skills in general,
* to get a good idea of the writing style you need to follow as a student and researcher,
* to know how to use effective transitions and signposts.
\end{code}

Any help would be appreciated.

Answer: Here is a bit of a generic answer for any kind of text. I'm not sure this is particularly good for the specific example but I believe it would be a good improvement for that also.

In your example code, you are using `\section` at the line starting with greenhouse effect. Try indenting that instead. Also the text following the `\subsection` should not be a separate paragraph, but continue the text.

You seem to write some paragraphs which have a start and an end, possibly for different sections. However, the paragraphs in \em{this} section of the text are not meant to be separate sections. That is the reason why `\section` and `\subsection`  are only used after `subsection` and not in the middle of \em{that} section.

To help improve this section, it would be good to know what the text is about. I think the greenhouse effect is mentioned too many times for this to stand? That is, it might be too obvious that the `subsection` is about greenhouse effect.

So instead, maybe you could introduce your reader to a topic: global warming, for example, (don't forget to introduce it!). Then, in the `\subsection`, you could explain why greenhouse effect, instead? Maybe have another `\subsection` for something else about why greenhouse effect instead?

This is a kind of \em{topic-based} structure. It is good to know what the topic is and what it should entail. For example if I write "focusing on the greenhouse effect" I don't really tell you what else the section consists of, but if it's "greenhouse effect: explanation, causes, etc" that would be better.

In addition, you have a lot of bullet points in this section, which don't seem to be related to anything. I don't know whether it is relevant to your text to have a bullet-point explanation about the difference between qualitative and quantitative lectures. There's a lot of unnecessary context and not very much concrete information here and there with the use of the `\item`: that is to say that, for example, all the links could be incorporated into the text without `\item`s.

I hope that makes sense. Otherwise tell me and I'll fix it :D

Comment: I am learning this by myself and this is the text I was given. I just wanted to make it look better, as my supervisor said. But honestly I can't quite follow this answer. Can you give an example of what you mean by a topic-based structure?

Comment: Also are there websites for learning writing for academic English. I would prefer them over a book. The book is really expensive!

Comment: By topic I mean "this section is about greenhouse effect". That way you can write a section about it without having to actually mention greenhouse effect a lot. It is the topic of the section. "For example" would then be "global warming" if it's a section on that. It could also be "what is a lecture" or whatever. The point is that the "section" then has a topic, so it can be about only that without referencing it often for something else.

Comment: There are tons of good English websites. Look around. I don't know any good online course material on it :)
